sourceDesc.p: Wellington City Libraries book of typed transcriptions. Spine title "Hadfield, Typescript (amended) letters 1833-1854". Corrected by Gillian Ryan 1960. (page 88)
Re-typed and encoded into TEI by Melissa Bryant, 20.11.15

body.p: I go on much as usual here. I have however been moving about lately- I was at Wanganui (Mason’s station) about five weeks ago, I saw the Dawsons there, who were quite well & very kind & civil to me- On my return from that place I went to Port Nicholson, & then went about 50 miles beyond it to a place called Wairarapa, which I had never visited before, the residents there are new comers, who having been beaten formerly in their wars had deserted their land, but who have now lately returned. I did not see many of them as they were in the woods, looking for food, having not yet any regular plantations- I had an uncomfortable trip there as there was cold rain every day, & some of the cliffs could only be passed by wading into the sea up to my waist- I passed another week at Port Nicholson & baptised about 30 natives there with whom I was much pleased- I officiated there as usual to an English congregation, to whom notice was given in the public papers. People came to hear me preach, tho’ I hear that many consider me an enthusiast &c – Christs little flock how – ever must profit – I am happy to say, that I am relieved of the charge now as Mr. Cole is appointed there. The bishop has arrived here though, I have not seen him as he was obliged to go to Nelson, I expect to see him on his return in a week or two- I do not know what he will do with me..or whether I shall remain where I am or not. The Bishop I hear is much interested in the Natives & has already some knowledge of their language. Maunsell has published a grammar, which however I have not seen He is a cleaver fellow the only man we have who knows the language well- Many of our good friends here that W. Williams knows the language & they leave the translations for him while they under-rate Maunsells ability which always amazes me – Our N. Z. New Test, is a poor thing; which is vexatious when we have Maunsell here. The natives around me continue to give me satisfaction & afford me comfort, tho’ some serve the devil & give me pain at times- I am sorry to say that they monopolize all my thoughts and the rest of the world engages but little of my attention. Such a creature am I. I would however, I think, to go among the Chinese.

I am very comfortable here; every body without exception is civil & kind to me, wherever I go, & my friends the St Hills are particularly, so, I am enjoying better health at the present time than I have for some years- Dr Fitzgerald did me much good, through the blessing of God- He persuaded me to eat and drink more and gave me some .

I must however take care that the body does not get the upper hand- I now keep a goat & a great many fowls, so that I have milk & eggs in abundance. I am able also to eat potatoes which I did not taste for years – So you see that I take care of myself though I be absent from you who used to take care of me. I trust to know shortly that you are all well, & enjoying the favour & blessing of the Lord, living in love & peace in the prospect of a better home which Jesus has purchased for us with his blood.
Please to remember me to all my kind friends; I ought to write to many, but I have not time and writing becomes a task to me. O Hadfield
